title: 111_hr4219
content:
The "National Commission on American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009" establishes a Commission in the legislative branch to oversee the recovery and reinvestment efforts. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with a limit of 5 members from the same political party. Non-governmental appointees are ineligible for membership. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by leaders, with a limit of 5 from the same party. Members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The appointed members serve as the chairperson and vice chairperson of the Commission. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by leaders, with a limit of 5 from the same party. Members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The appointed members serve as the chairperson and vice chairperson of the Commission. The Commission shall meet at the call of the chairperson or a majority of its members, with six members constituting a quorum. Vacancies in the membership do not affect the Commission's duties or powers. Meetings are held in public as deemed appropriate by the Commission. The Commission's duties are outlined in Section 4 of the Act. The Commission is tasked with investigating the number of jobs saved or created by the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, the circumstances surrounding these jobs, and the effectiveness of measures to prevent improper payments. They are also required to make recommendations for changes to the Act to create more jobs and prevent improper fund allocation. The Commission investigates improper fund allocation under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. When investigating, they must consider Government Accountability Office material and can conduct further investigations if necessary. SEC. 5. HEARINGS AND EVIDENCE. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed for the Act. Hearings must be held in public when deemed appropriate. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations required by the Act, with the ability to delegate these powers. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations required by the Act. Subpoenas can be approved by the chairperson, vice chairperson, or a majority of the Commission members, and must be served accordingly. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Subpoenas must be served by authorized individuals and enforcement can be pursued through a court order if necessary. Failure to obey a court order under this paragraph may result in punishment by the court for civil contempt. SEC. 6. ASSISTANCE FROM FEDERAL AGENCIES, CONTRACTS, GIFTS AND POSTAL SERVICES. The Commission may request information from Federal agencies, with the duty to comply. The General Services Administration can provide administrative support if requested. Other departments and agencies can offer financial or other assistance. The Commission may also enter into contracts. The Commission can enter into contracts, accept gifts, and use postal services as needed to carry out the Act. The Commission is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The chairperson, with the vice chairperson's consultation, can appoint a director and other staff for the Commission, setting their pay according to Commission rules. The pay for these positions cannot exceed that of a level V position in the Executive Schedule. The Director and staff can be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Commission can procure temporary services under specific regulations, with rates not exceeding those of a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. EXPENSES FOR MEMBERS. Each Commission member will be compensated at a rate not exceeding the daily equivalent of a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. They will also receive travel expenses according to applicable provisions. SEC. 10. REPORTS.

The Commission must submit a final report to the President and Congress before the end of the 18-month period after the enactment of this Act, containing findings and recommendations. Interim reports may also be submitted as deemed necessary. All reports required by this Act must be made available to the public.

SEC. 11. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. SEC. 11. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will end 60 days after submitting its final report. It can wrap up administrative activities during this period. SEC. 12. FUNDING. $5,000,000 is authorized for this Act.
